Package org.tensorics.core.tensor

This package contains the base classes for tensoric elements.

See: Description

  • Interface Summary 
    Interface Description
    Tensor<E>
    The top interface for Tensor like objects.
    TensorBuilder<E>
    The interface any builder of a tensor has to implement
    TensorView<V>
    Marks a tensor, which is a view on one or more other tensor(s).
    VerificationCallback<S>
    A callback that can be passed to a builder so that it can check any new scalar added if it is conform to certain criteria.
  • Class Summary 
    Class Description
    AbstractTensorBuilder<E>  
    BroadcastedTensorView<V>
    Lets a tensors appear as a tensor with a bigger shape.
    Context Deprecated
    context of a tensor will be directly a position
    Coordinates
    Utility methods to handle coordinates
    ImmutableTensor<T>
    Default Implementation of Tensor.
    ImmutableTensor.Builder<S>
    A builder for an immutable tensor.
    OngoingPut<T>
    Inner Builder object to manage between positions and values.
    Position
    Defines the position of a value within a tensor in the N-dimensional coordinate space.
    PositionPair
    A pair of positions, usually representing a position in the left tensor of an operation and its corresponding position in the right tensor.
    Positions
    Contains utility methods for position objects.
    Positions.DimensionStripper
    A functional object to transform positions to other positions with the dimensions stripped as given in the constructor.
    Shape
    Defines the shape of a tensor.
    Shape.Builder
    The builder for a tensor shape.
    Shapes
    Contains utility methods to deal with tensor shapes.
    TensorPair<V>
    A pair of tensors which are used together in several occasions.

Package org.tensorics.core.tensor Description

This package contains the base classes for tensoric elements. There are in general two aspects taken into account by this hierarchy:
  1. Deferrence: A tensoric can either be a real object containing data or it can be 'deferred', meaning that is simply a placeholder for the real object, which will be determined later.
  2. Tensoric base types: The base type for all real data-holding objects is the Tensor. A special version of it is a scalar, which has zero dimensions (order, rank). A special treatment is sometimes required for the elements of the tensors themselves: These can be java objects of any type. However, if calculations have to be performed by them, than a mathematical environment is required for them.
An overview of the actual types is depicted in the following diagram:
